item.title: Trump to Impose 25% Tariff on Japan, South Korea
item.description: President Donald Trump announced 25% tariffs on goods from Japan and South Korea starting August 1, as part of his effort to impose unilateral rates on countries without trade deals with the US. Kailey Leinz reports.

item.title: S&P 500 Slides as Trump Sets Japan, Korea Tariffs: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks fell and the dollar rose as President Donald Trump said the US will impose a 25% tariff on imports from Japan and South Korea starting next month — sinking currencies of both nations. Longer-dated Treasuries underperformed on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: The logo for Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) displayed on a screen at the Exchange Square complex in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Hong Kong's stock exchange reported its highest quarterly profit in nearly four years after China's stimulus measures boosted trading and listing volume.

item.title: Trump’s One Big Reverse Stimulus
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump displays the signed bill during a ceremony for the One Big Beautiful Bill Act on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, July 4, 2025. Trump signed his $3.4 trillion budget bill into law Friday, enshrining an extension of tax cuts, temporary new breaks for tipped workers and funding to crack down on illegal immigration. Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Stocks Sink as Trump to Impose 25% Tariffs on Japan, South Korea
item.description: US equities tumbled in afternoon trade Monday as trade fears returned in full force, with President Donald Trump set to impose 25% tariffs on Japan and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: A container ship at the Yokkaichi Port in Yokkaichi, Japan.

item.title: Archegos Employees Entitled to $33 Million, Judge Says
item.description: A federal judge ruled that a group of former Archegos Capital Management employees, including an analyst who worked closely with founder Bill Hwang, are owed $33 million for losses they suffered when the firm collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, exits federal court in New York, US, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Hwang's fate will soon be in the hands of the jury, with both the prosecution and defense set to make closing arguments in his fraud and market manipulation trial.

item.title: European Natural Gas Prices Edge Up as US Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: European natural gas prices edged higher as traders eyed US President Donald Trump’s fast-approaching tariff deadline and the impact levies will have on global economic activity.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

item.title: Daimler Truck Announces Fresh Share Buyback Program
item.description: Daimler Truck Holding AG will buy back €2 billion ($2.34 billion) of its own shares, extending a policy of returning cash to shareholders even as the transition to low-emission vehicles adds to costs.
item.dc:creator: William Wilkes

media:content.media:description: A Mercedes-Benz eActros LongHaul electric truck, manufactured by Daimler Truck Holding AG, on display at the IAA Transportation show in Hanover, Germany, on Monday, Sept. 19, 2022. Global leaders Daimler Truck Holding AG and Volvo AB are joining dozens of commercial-vehicle makers in Germany this week to showcase their latest electric semis, with more zero-emissions vehicles debuting at the IAA Transportation show than ever before.

item.title: Ousted CEO Escalates Dye & Durham Power Struggle, Calls on Company to Sell
item.description: A firm headed by the former chief executive officer of Dye & Durham Ltd. says the Canadian software company should put itself for sale. The shares surged.

item.title: BP Appoints Ex-Shell Veteran and CFO Simon Henry to Board
item.description: BP Plc appointed Simon Henry, a longtime Shell veteran, to its board of directors as the UK energy giant seeks to turn around its fortunes.
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Ferman

media:content.media:description: Simon Henry, chief financial officer of Royal Dutch Shell Plc, speaks during a presentation to investors at the company's capitals markets day in London, U.K., on Tuesday, June 7, 2016. Shell cut spending plans further and promised increased savings following its record purchase of BG Group Plc, as Europe’s largest oil company continues to adjust to the slump in energy prices.

item.title: Brazil Coffee Growers Plant More Trees in Bid to Boost Output
item.description: Brazil, which already ships three in every 10 bags of coffee traded globally, is planting more trees in a bid to ramp up output.
item.dc:creator: Dayanne Sousa

media:content.media:description: A worker inspects coffee trees during a harvest on a farm in Guaxupe, Minas Gerais state, Brazil, on Wednesday, June 2, 2021. The severe drought in agricultural powerhouse Brazil is shaking up the world's crop markets again, this time because farmers in the top exporting country are finding they can't meet sales agreements made months ago.

item.title: Indian Retail Traders Lose $12 Billion Trading Equity Options
item.description: Individuals in India lost over 1 trillion rupees ($12.2 billion) during the year ended March, trading equity derivatives in the world’s top destination for such products, according to a study by the country’s securities regulator.
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Treasury Yields Climb Ahead of Auctions Amid Tariffs Uncertainty
item.description: Treasury yields rose Monday led by long-maturity tenors as investors preoccupied with the potential fallout of US tariffs looked ahead to auctions later this week.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill

item.title: Oil Edges Up as Saudis Bet Market Can Absorb OPEC+ Output Hike
item.description: Oil crept higher as Saudi Arabia surprised customers in Asia by hiking prices for its main crude grade, signaling a vote of confidence that the market can absorb extra OPEC barrels.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Jack Wittels

item.title: Donohoe Retains Eurogroup Role to Push Currency’s Ascendancy
item.description: Paschal Donohoe won reelection as president of the euro area’s group of finance ministers, retaining a leading role in the region’s efforts to enhance the profile of its common currency.

item.title: Cathie Wood Targets Investor Jitters With Buffer ETFs Designed to Limit Equity Losses
item.description: Cathie Wood’s Ark Investment Management LLC is moving into the fast-growing market for buffer ETFs designed to limit equity losses, at a time when her tech funds continue to bleed assets.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Lee

media:content.media:description: Cathie Wood, chief executive officer of Ark Investment Management LLC, following a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. We expect real GDP in the US to accelerate, Wood said.

item.title: Musk Needs to Focus on Tesla, Not Trump, Says Azoria CEO
item.description: Azoria CEO James Fishback says Elon Musk should focus his time on Tesla and SpaceX and not trying to sabotage President Donald Trump. Fishback, a shareholder, says if Musk doesn't want to be a fulltime CEO, he "should tell us now." Fishback speaks on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Falls as Investors Eye US Tariff Moves and Dollar
item.description: Gold fell as the dollar rose at the start of a potentially volatile week that will see US trading partners rush to finalize deals with the Trump administration ahead of a July 9 tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

item.title: Hunter Point CEO on the PE Investor Pivot
item.description: Last month, Hunter Point Capital agreed to acquire a 16% stake in Equitix, an international infrastructure investor and fund manager, at a valuation near $2 billion. Since the deal, Equitix's portfolio has grown to nearly $16 billion in assets under management. CEO and co-Founder Avi Kalichstein joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the partnership. (Corrected guest name and title) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Why Jane Street Was a Target in India’s Option Trading Crackdown
item.description: India has gone from being a small player in the highly speculative equity derivatives market to the world’s largest, all within just five years. Daily turnover in the market now sits at around $3 trillion.

item.title: Israel Holds Rates and Cuts Growth Forecast for This Year
item.description: Israel’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged for the 12th consecutive time, giving a recent rally in the shekel more time to slow inflation and pave the way for lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at Carmel market in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Israel launched airstrikes across Iran on Friday morning, targeting nuclear facilities and killing senior military commanders in a major escalation that could spark a broad war in the Middle East.

item.title: Tesla Investors Are Tired of Distractions, Says Blair
item.description: Jed Dorsheimer, William Blair Group Head of Energy and Power Technologies, downgraded Tesla to the equivalent of a hold. He says investors are tired of the distractions caused by CEO Elon Musk. The stock is already down 28% this year. Dorsheimer is on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dollar Jumps Ahead of Trump Tariff Deadline
item.description: The dollar rose against currencies globally, climbing to its strongest level in more than a week on speculation Donald Trump’s trade tariffs won’t hurt the US economy as badly as feared or require aggressive interest-rate cuts to remedy.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu, Malavika Kaur Makol, Matthew Burgess
